awd_titl_txt: Planning: CRISES: Center for Interdisciplinary Research on Housing and Homelessness
awd_abstract_narration:
The housing and homelessness crises are caused by a complex web of factors ranging from lack of housing production and zoning policies to structural racism in labor markets and criminal justice systems. The consequences of homelessness for individuals and families are profound, and these crises strain public services and systems. Research on housing and homelessness is often siloed, and fragmentation in funding and program delivery across housing and homelessness organizations undermines effective solutions. This planning project focuses on the development of an interdisciplinary research Center that brings housing and homelessness research communities together. The project considers the social, health, economic, and policy dimensions of these intersecting crises, and emphasizes the structural reforms that are needed to reduce homelessness and improve the well-being of individuals. It also aims to inform the public debate on housing and homelessness by replacing misconceptions with data and accessible research. 
 
Research on housing and homelessness is often not informed by interdisciplinary research approaches spanning economics, psychology, anthropology, geography, sociology, and other social science disciplines. The project plans for interdisciplinary research to advance knowledge by integrating the perspectives of housing and homelessness research, employing a dynamic rather than static framework of homelessness, and integrating structural and individual approaches to the experiences of different demographic and risk groups. Planned activities will help inform policy solutions to the housing and homelessness crises, such as identifying a strategic interdisciplinary research agenda, improving the data ecosystem for social science research on housing and homelessness, and supporting community participatory research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Housing costs are consistently cited as among the most important issues to Americans, and for good reason --- affordable housing is one of the most urgent issues facing the United States. Research has consistently shown that the lack of affordable housing is a key driver of homelessness in the United States: In 2023, about 653,000 people in the U.S. were identified as homeless on a single night, and nearly 40 percent of those were unsheltered. The consequences of homelessness for individuals and families are profound, negatively impacting a wide range of outcomes including health, education, earnings, and mortality. The housing and homelessness crises also puts a strain on public services and systems, compromising public safety and quality of life, fiscal solvency, and urban governance. 

 

This NSF CRISES planning grant resulted in a concept for the UC Center for Interdisciplinary Research on Housing and Homelessness ("Center"), which will generate research and evidence to inform national policy solutions to the crises of housing and homelessness. Policymakers need better information to expand access to housing and homelessness services that improve individual and community outcomes, as well as to prevent homelessness from happening in the first place.

 

The Center assembles a group of interdisciplinary researchers with expertise in housing and homelessness for perhaps the first time, providing space for collaboration across disciplines that has been far too rare. Principal Investigators and other participants include researchers affiliated with the California Policy Lab at UCLA and UC Berkeley, UC Berkeley Terner Center for Housing Innovation, UCSF Benioff Homelessness and Housing Initiative, and the UCLA Lewis Center for Regional Policy Studies. Collectively, these researchers are driven by the goal of developing policy-relevant studies that directly impact public decision-making. Through this work, we have developed long-standing partnerships in California, which grant us data access and research opportunities in a state that accounts for 28% of all people experiencing homelessness and 49% of all people experiencing unsheltered homelessness in the United States. The root causes and solutions to these crises in California are representative of national trends, and evidence generated in California can guide not only state policy, but federal efforts to end homelessness as well.

 

The NSF CRISES Planning Grant provided funding for the research team to build out a vision and governance structure for the Center, documented in five deliverables: (1) a Research Agenda that describes the most pressing policy questions for interdisciplinary research; (2) a Data Strategy that identifies data sources currently accessible to Center affiliates and proposes new data collection and linkages; (3) an Engagement Plan to promote policy impact through community participatory research and community and policymaker engagement; (4) a Training Plan for postdoctoral mentoring, opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, and plans to increase the participation of underrepresented groups in research; and (5) a Governance Plan that maps out the Center's mission, core activities, decision making processes, proposed staffing, and procedures for developing, funding, and communicating interdisciplinary research. With these deliverables in place, the UC Center for Interdisciplinary Research on Housing and Homelessness is ready to apply to the NSF's planned CRISES Center Request for Proposals. 

 

If funded by the NSF CRISES Center grant, the Center would catalyze actionable, scientific evidence that would transform the study of housing and homelessness. The Center would conduct research that currently is not possible due to limitations of data infrastructure and the interdisciplinary nature of many of the research questions core to the study of housing and homelessness. Additionally, the Center would leverage existing, external partnerships with government agencies, policy change agents, and lived experts --- and develop new ones --- to inform the Center's research priorities and identify emerging opportunities for research. This would ensure Center research is directly relevant for policy decisions. The Center would disseminate its findings through coordinated communication to practitioners, policymakers and the academic community. The long-term impact of the Center will be to advance key scientific research on homelessness and its causes, as well as provide policymakers with much-needed evidence to help end the national housing and homelessness crisis.

 

References

Colburn, Gregg, and Clayton Page Aldern. 2022. Homelessness Is a Housing Problem: How Structural Factors Explain U.S. Patterns. First Edition. Oakland (Calif.): University of California Press.

De Sousa, Tanya et al. 2023. "The 2023 Annual Homeless Assessment Report (AHAR) to Congress, Part 1: Point-in-Time Estimates of Homelessness." Washington, D.C.: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, 2023. 

Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University (2024). The State of the Nation's Rental Housing. Cambridge, MA: Joint Center for Housing Studies. https://www.jchs.harvard.edu/americas-rental-housing-2024

Shinn, Marybeth, and Jill Khadduri. 2020. In the Midst of Plenty: Homelessness and What To Do About It. 1st edition. Hoboken, NJ: Wiley-Blackwell.

Willison, Charley E. 2021. Ungoverned and Out of Sight: Public Health and the Political Crisis of Homelessness in the United States. Oxford University Press.
